 Now, each replicator will require certain chemicals to produce the copy from, other chemicals may help the reaction and other chemicals will be produced as by-products from these rections. Now, it is again likely that some of the by-products from some replicators would help other replicators. And sometimes groups of replicators would form (a-<b-<c-<d-<a, say) where a's by-product helps b, b helps c, c helps d and d helps a.
 
 These groups are called hyper-cycles. Hyper-cycles are significant because they allow the replicators to solve a significant problem - small replicators aren't very good and so have a maximum length they can be before the poorness of their replication prevents from producing a reasonable number of exact copies.
 
 From hyper-cycles came later replicators such as RNA, it is perhaps also possible that some of these hyper-cycles produced protective lipid-bubbles (psuedo-cells?) to protect themselves.
 
 Things then passed through a stage popularly known as 'RNA-world' where RNA formed the most common replicator. Somewhere among this RNA-based life the first cells emerged. DNA also emerged as a better storage method than RNA - it is a matter of debate whether cells or DNA came first.
 
 This first cell was nothing like modern cells. It probably had no nucleus, and certainly no organelles.
 
 You may well feel the above is highly speculative, and you'd be right. We don't know how life originated on earth - the research needed is being done now. That's because it's science. Science doesn't have all the answers, it doesn't have complete truth - it just gets closer all the time.
 
 Research has shown that amino acids can be formed from inorganic materials by natural processes. Research has shown that polypeptides can self-replicate. Research has shown that RNA can self-replicate. Research has shown the plausability of the RNA-world model. Research has produced likely life-trees tracing all life back to something akin to the Archae and hyperthermophiles. While mathematical modelling can demonstrate the theoretical possibility of the various steps in the model above.

The heartbeat of a rat is required because it maintains the chemistry of the rat, without the pumping of the blood to bring oxygen to the organs and take damaging by-products away the chemistry of the rat will change. If you somehow stopped the heart but kept these processes going (along with the other functions the blood performs) the rat would carry on living.

 No, it would not. Would burning a book, and then taking the heat away bring the book back? Life is maintained by complicated chemisty, when that chemistry breaks down the damage done cannot be reversed simply by restoring the presence of the maintaining influence. Just as with other chemical processes (although life is particularly complicated).
 
 
the thing is, life of itself is apparently not simply dependant on physical/molecular composition. say we have 2 twin animals, one is dead, one is alive. there is something else added that makes the difference between two groups of identical molecules (a living body and a dead body)

 
 A living body, and a dead body are not identical, the chemical and physical processes going on are different. These differences cannot be easily reversed. There is no need to postulate a magic ingredient to make it work.
